content:
This is a cool clash, and the optimisation part makes it quite fun.

One missing edge case though is a situation like "No, we can't" where one of the three is much less populous than the other two, but where after that one dies, the final winner is not actually the animal with the highest population at the point the third one dies.

I managed to get 100% by simply subtracting the (minimum population - 1) from all three and then adding a clause to my while loop to stop after 1000 iterations. My while loop would have timed out otherwise, because I'd not optimised for situations where the three populations were drastically different, but I got lucky because I still got the right answer since the population that died first was the predator for the winner, so the remaining loops didn't change the answer (since I just picked the max population as the winner at the end).

A test case that I would have failed would be a situation where after the first population goes extinct, its prey actually has the next lowest population. This means that the prey would be the predator of the animal with the largest population, and could just keep killing them until they died.


e.g.
CHICKENS 98765432
    SNAKES 987654321
       FOXES 9876543

My code would answer "SNAKES 977776780", but the correct answer should be "CHICKENS 88888890".

✅ Approved the contribution.
Comment: the instructions are clear, and it is fun enough and sufficient time is allowed to be able to create a solution.

✅ Approved the contribution.
Comment: I like this puzzle, as it requires one to be careful with cases

✅ Approved the contribution.
Comment: Explains the problem aptly and clearly.
Good for train loop inception !
i love this guy

I think it's an interesting CoC, but maybe you should shorten the example into the goal section. I think it would make the section cleaner. You could give an example like : 
1 2 3
1 1 2
1 1 1
0 1 1
0 1 1
0 1 0

Stub generator
* Please provide a string and an integer instead a single string.

Input section
* Please change "interger" to "integer".

* Please add "separated by a space".

* Please mention that [[NAME]] is one of the three animals: {{CHICKENS}}, {{FOXES}} and {{SNAKES}}.

* Please add a description of what [[N]] is.

Output section
* Please change "interger" to "integer".

* Please add "separated by a space".

* Please change "exctint" to "extinct".

Constraints section
* Please add the constraint to show the lower and upper limits of [[N]].

Cases
* Please fix all the typos: "CHIKENS" should be spelled as "CHICKENS".

Goal section
* It seems to me that the statement does not explain clearly what your solution code is trying to achieve. Would you please rewrite the explanation and possibly add an example showing the steps?

By the way, I see that your solution needs to take into account of ties. In my opinion, if the animals take turn to act, ties do not matter, and which animal currently has the minimum population also does not matter.

I'll take the first test as an example, to show how I interpret the problem based on the current statement:

Initial: 5 chickens, 3 snakes, 4 foxes

Turn 1.1: Chickens kill snakes. There are enough chickens to kill all 3 snakes.
=> 5 chickens, 0 snakes, 4 foxes

Turn 1.2: Snakes kill foxes. There are no snakes, so all foxes remain.
=> 5 chickens, 0 snakes, 4 foxes

Turn 1.3: Foxes kill chickens. Chickens outnumber foxes, so only 4 chickens are killed.
=> 1 chicken, 0 snakes, 4 foxes

Turn 2.1: Chickens kill snakes. There are no snakes to kill.
=> 1 chicken, 0 snakes, 4 foxes

Turn 2.2: Snakes kill foxes. There are no snakes, so all foxes remain.
=> 1 chicken, 0 snakes, 4 foxes

Turn 2.3: Foxes kill chickens. There are enough foxes to kill the remaining chicken.
=> 0 chickens, 0 snakes, 4 foxes.

Hence, 4 foxes remain (vs your answer: 2 foxes).

* I'll try to respond to your earlier comment if I can, after the above is clarified.

Thanks.

Hi.

At first I thought this might be too easy even for a CoC but it turned out to be trickier than it seemed, specially if big numbers are involved.

With small numbers, it can be solved with a naive algorithm that simulates each kill.

If big numbers are roughly equals, like in validator 8 "Yes, we can", the naive algorithm can be easily optimized to handle the case.

But if the big numbers are very different, the naive algorithm will always time out. For validator 9 "No we can't" another logic must be implemented, with a couple of tricky cases.

I am wondering if it is ok for a CoC or if I should remove validator 9.
Or should I keep it but make this an easy puzzle instead ? Or can I do both ?

What about validator 8 ? It seems to me ok for a CoC. 
I could also add a validator with the value 0 for one or two animals, that might not be too hard to pass either.

Let me know what you think and thanks for the feedback.

I think this will make quite an interesting and challenging CoC. Your selection of the cases makes sure that even the naive algorithm can pass the majority of the cases, but only the optimised algorithm can pass all the cases. Good job.

Ok. I see the instructions are not clear, thought I'm not sure how I should write them.
The idea is that only one animal is killed at a time.
The chickens kill one snake, then the snakes kill one fox, etc.

For that example, that would do
5 3 4
5 2 4
5 2 3
4 2 3
4 1 3
4 1 2
3 1 2
3 0 2
2 0 2
1 0 2
0 0 2 => 2 foxes

Thanks for the feedback. I think I fixed most of the issues you mentionned, but I don't know what to do with the stub generaor.
Thanks. I did it.

c=s=f=0
3.times do
  l = line = gets.chomp
  v = line[/\d+/].to_i
  c = v if l[0]=="C"
  s = v if l[0]=="S"
  f = v if l[0]=="F"
end
c,s,f = [c,s,f].map{|i| i - [c,s,f].min + 1 }
while [c,s,f].count(0) < 2 && ($.+=1)<1000
  if c > 0
    s -=1
  end
  if s > 0
    f -=1
  end
  if f > 0
    c -=1
  end
end
i = [c,s,f].index([c,s,f].max)
puts ["CHICKENS SNAKES FOXES".split[i], [c,s,f][i]]*" "

OK, please let me know when you are done, and I'll take a second look at it :)

Also, I'd suggest to add a note to the statement that the brute-force approach should be able to handle all the cases but only an optimised algorithm can handle the cases involving large numbers.

Oh, sorry, I missed your comment on the stub generator. I've done some experimentation just now. It looks like the stub generator is not able to process the case to read a string and an integer in the same line. So, please ignore that comment.

Sorry again.
Oh, is there a reason to provide the names as inputs if they're always provided in the same order? I mean, you may provide just the numbers.

I tought about that but I decided that it made the test cases easier to read. The price is that one must split the string and cast to integer. Which is more user friendly ? That is debatable.

So I think I fixed all the issues you mentionned, all the stupid typos and I  tried to clarify the goals.

Thanks for the feedback. Let me know if I missed something.
Thank you. I understand your reason now. Although I'd still prefer providing just three numbers as the inputs, it's your choice so I won't press on with that. :)

Another advantage is that one doesn't have to copy the strings 'CHICKENS' etc. in the code. But you are right in the sense that replacing "chickens always start" with "the first one always starts" and rewriting a couple of test cases would make more sense and not change the algorithm. I'll do that.
I've thought about the strings actually: you may include the three animals' names in the write statement - that's actually more direct in helping the clash players!
